page.title: 15ECOLOGY 2
page.content: The area contains both alkaline & acid habitats,varying according to the de- pth of clay-with-flints over chalk.Wi- ld clematis is frequent as a chalk indicator species. The woodlands are mostly mixed deciduous with some small beech stands.The extensive Hockeridge Woods are also planted with a variety of conifers & are very rich in Autumn fungi.Many of the hedges have a high species count indicating many hundreds yrs of age.The Hockeridge Woods conta- in ancient boundry banks, with now ma- ture beeches on them.The roadside ver- ges are frequently flower-species rich & managed by cutting regime designed to conserve the diversity.Badger setts are frequent, especially favouring the ancient chalk extraction pits.Introdu- ced Muntjac deer are increasing, often entering larger gardens.The Chiltern glis-glis invades local soft spots.
